issues.description: Contradictory instructions about where to initialize the shared stock: the problem text tells students to initialize attributes (orders and stock) in the SealSaloon constructor (no-arg constructor), but elsewhere the problem explicitly requires the stock attribute to be static and final. A static final field cannot be sensibly initialized per-instance in the constructor. This creates an impossible-to-follow instruction for students (should stock be an instance field initialized in the constructor, or a static final field initialized at declaration?).
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the specification: decide whether stock is a per-instance field initialized in the constructor, or a shared static final field initialized at declaration. If stock must be shared across all SealSaloon instances, state that stock is static final and show/describe that it is initialized at declaration (or via a static initializer). Remove the sentence that requires initializing stock in the instance constructor to avoid the contradiction.

issues.description: The problem UML and textual description indicate checkOrderReady() should be a void method, but the provided solution implements checkOrderReady() returning boolean. This return-type mismatch between the specification and the solution reference can confuse students about the required signature and intended use of the method.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method signature consistent across artifacts. Either update the problem statement/UML to allow/expect a boolean return value (and document its meaning), or change the solution to implement checkOrderReady() as void (and rely on side-effects/printing as described). Prefer matching the specification (void) unless the boolean return is intentionally useful and documented.

issues.description: Minor inconsistency between the UML fragment and the later textual requirements regarding which SealSaloon methods/attributes must be static: the UML does not mark calculateTotalPrice and acceptSupplyDelivery as static, but the text later explicitly requires these methods (and the stock attribute) to be static. Students relying solely on the UML diagram might miss the static requirement.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the UML and the textual specification consistent. Either annotate the UML to show the static methods/field, or remove/relax the textual requirement. Best is to update the UML so calculateTotalPrice and acceptSupplyDelivery are clearly marked as static and to annotate stock as static final.
